block.p: Dr. Nathaniel Geoffrey Lew and Jason Paymar Lorber are to celebrate their partnership in a commitment ceremony today at the Cameron-Stanford House in Oakland, Calif. Rabbi Evan L. Goodman is to officiate.

Dr. Lew, 36, is an assistant professor of music at St. Michael's College in Colchester, Vt., and the director of the school's choral program. He is also a tenor in Counterpoint, an a cappella vocal ensemble based in Belmont, Vt. He received bachelor's degrees from Yale and Cambridge University and a doctorate in musicology from the University of California. His mother, Prof. Ellen Handler Spitz of Baltimore, is a professor of visual arts at the University of Maryland at Baltimore County. His father, Dr. John S. Lew of Ossining, N.Y., retired as a mathematician at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

Dr. Nathaniel Geoffrey Lew and Jason Paymar Lorber are to celebrate their partnership in a commitment ceremony today at the Cameron-Stanford House in Oakland, Calif. Rabbi Evan L. Goodman is to officiate.

Dr. Lew, 36, is an assistant professor of music at St. Michael's College in Colchester, Vt., and the director of the school's choral program. He is also a tenor in Counterpoint, an a cappella vocal ensemble based in Belmont, Vt. He received bachelor's degrees from Yale and Cambridge University and a doctorate in musicology from the University of California. His mother, Prof. Ellen Handler Spitz of Baltimore, is a professor of visual arts at the University of Maryland at Baltimore County. His father, Dr. John S. Lew of Ossining, N.Y., retired as a mathematician at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

Mr. Lorber, also 36, operates Aplomb Consulting in Burlington, Vt., and San Francisco, which advises AIDS and gay organizations on research and marketing. He is also a stand-up comedian in Burlington. He graduated from the University of California and received an M.B.A. from Stanford. His mother, Judith P. Lorber, lives in Long Beach, Calif., and is a substitute teacher in its public elementary schools. His father, Dr. Morris L. Lorber of Torrance, Calif., is a retired neurologist who practiced in Gardena, Calif.

Dr. Lew and Mr. Lorber met at a San Francisco synagogue in 1999, when Mr. Lorber entered to find a packed house and took the only available seat, next to Dr. Lew. They chatted during breaks in the service.
''When we talked, it was like he was reading off my checklist,'' Mr. Lorber recalled. ''I thought, 'Wow! He meets all the criteria.' ''
